Then he set him on his own animal and brought him to an inn and took care of him. 35 And the next day he took out two denarii and gave them to the innkeeper, saying, ‘Take care of him, and whatever more you spend, I will repay you when I come back.’ Luke 10:36 Which of these three, do you think, proved to be a neighbor to the man who fell among the robbers?” Luke 10:37 He said, “The one who showed him mercy.” And Jesus said to him, “You go, and do likewise.” In the early church, the traditional interpretation of this passage was that Jesus is the Good Samaritan (whom we should emulate), the church is the inn, the oil and wine represent the sacraments of baptism (the water of baptism was followed by the application of chrism in the early church) and the Eucharist, and the Samaritan's return is Judgment Day. Post-Christian cultures devolve into tribalism - e.g., people are less likely to help a young woman being stabbed on a metro if that person is outside of their subgroup within the larger society. In contrast, I have known Christians in the south from many backgrounds - whether white, black, yellow or brown - who have shown great kindness to people outside of their group because they love and follow the One who is truly the "Good Samaritan." Church attendance, of course, declines in southern cities when they grow beyond a certain point and the local culture is replaced by people from many regions (leaving no shared sense of right and wrong, virtues to inculcate, and vices to avoid). The ultimate solution to this is not political (although the world is a better place when we vote for virtuous policies and oppose bad policies).
